lesson.name: Lesson 8.6: Rewriting Quadratic Expressions in Factored Form, Part 1

page.title: 8.6.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will begin to rewrite quadratic expressions from standard to factored form. You will look at expressions of the form \((x + m)(x + n)\) and \((x − m)(x − n)\) where \(m\) and \(n\) are positive.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Explain how the numbers in a quadratic expression in factored form relate to the numbers in an equivalent expression in standard form.
  • Rewrite a quadratic expression in standard form when given the quadratic expression in factored form.
  • Rewrite a quadratic expression in factored form when given the quadratic expression in the form of \(x^2+ bx + c\).

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 8.6.1: Finding and Reasoning Unknown Factors
  • 8.6.2: Using Diagrams to Understand Equivalent Expressions
    • 8.6.2: Self Check
    • 8.6.2: Additional Resources
  • 8.6.3: Rewriting Quadratic Expressions in Standard Form
    • 8.6.3: Self Check
    • 8.6.3: Additional Resources
  • 8.6.4: Finding the Missing Numbers in Pairs of Equivalent Expressions

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 8.6.5: Practice
  • 8.6.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 8.6.1: Finding and Reasoning Unknown Factors
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Examine the two puzzles that involve side lengths and areas of rectangles. Can you find the missing area in Figure A and the missing length in Figure B? Be prepared to explain your reasoning.

Figure A


  1. What is the missing area in Figure A above?

Enter the missing area.

Compare your answer:

20 sq. in.


Figure B


  1. What is the missing length in Figure B above?

Enter the missing length.

Compare your answer:

9 in.

page.title: 8.6.2: Using Diagrams to Understand Equivalent Expressions
page.contents:
Activity

Look at these two expressions.

\((x + 7)(x + 9)\)

\(x^2+ 16x + 63\)

We can show they are equivalent by using a diagram to break apart the different pieces.


 

\(x\)

7

\(x\)

\(x^2\)

\(7x\)

9

\(9x\)

63

The binomial factors \((x + 7)\) and \((x + 9)\) have been placed in the cells along the horizontal and vertical edge of the diagram.

To find the internal cells, the terms in each factor are multiplied together.

Then, the like terms in the product cells are combined. Notice that \(7x + 9x\) results in the linear term of our second expression, \(16x\) (from \(x^2+16x+63\)).

Use a diagram to show that each pair of expressions is equivalent. It is helpful to rewrite any subtraction expressions as adding the opposite before starting, as has been modeled in questions 2 and 5.


  1. \(x(x + 3)\) and \(x^2+ 3x\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(x(x + 3)\) and \(x^2+ 3x\)

 

\(x\)

0

\(x\)

\(x^2\)

0

3

\(3x\)

0

  1. \(x(x + (-6))\) and \(x^2−6x\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(x(x+ (-6))\) and \(x^2−6x\)

 

\(x\)

0

\(x\)

\(x^2\)

0

\(-6\)

\(-6x\)

0

  1. \((x + 2)(x + 4)\) and \(x^2+ 6x + 8\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\((x + 2)(x + 4)\) and \(x^2+6x+ 8\)

 

\(x\)

2

\(x\)

\(x^2\)

\(2x\)

4

\(4x\)

8

  1. \((x + 4)(x + 10)\) and \(x^2+14x +40\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\((x + 4)(x + 10)\) and \(x^2+ 14x + 40\)

 

\(x\)

4

\(x\)

\(x^2\)

\(4x\)

10

\(10x\)

40

  1. \((x + (-5))(x + (-1))\) and \(x^2− 6x + 5\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\((x + (-5))(x + (-1))\) and \(x^2− 6x + 5\)

 

\(x\)

–5

\(x\)

\(x^2\)

\(-5x\)

–1

\(-1x\)

5

  1. \((x − 1)(x − 7)\) and \(x^2− 8x + 7\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\((x − 1)(x − 7)\) and \(x^2− 8x + 7\)

Rewrite \((x − 1)(x − 7)\) as \((x + (-1))(x + (-7))\).

 

/(x\)

–1

\(x\)

\(x^2\)

\(-1x\)

–7

\(-7x\)

7


  1. Review the pairs of expressions that involve the product of two sums or two differences that you just diagramed. How is each expression in factored form (the first expression placed into the cells along the horizontal and vertical edge of the diagram) related to the equivalent expression in standard form (the second expression that results from the product cells)?

Enter your explanation.

Compare your answer:

Because the coefficients of the \(x\)-terms are both 1 in the factored form, when the two numbers that appear in factored form are added, the result is the coefficient of \(x\) in standard form. If those same two numbers are multiplied, the result is the constant term in standard form. (Note that this explanation relies on recasting every subtraction expression as adding the opposite.)

page.title: 8.6.2: Self Check
page.contents:
An expression in standard form is shown. The diagram below is equivalent to which expression in factored form?

\(x^2−13x + 42\)

\(x\)

-6

\(x\)

\(x^2\)

\(-6x\)

-7

\(-7x\)

42

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Use the diagram to help you convert from standard form to factored form. Look in the top-right and bottom-left squares for the numbers to use in the factored form. The answer is \((x − 6)(x − 7)\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This expression results in a linear term of \(+13x\) instead of the \(-13x\) we need. The answer is \((x − 6)(x − 7)\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This expression does not result in a constant term of \(+42\). The answer is \((x − 6)(x − 7)\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: Multiply \((x − 6)(x − 7)\) using FOIL. The result is \(x^2− 13x + 42\).

page.title: 8.6.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Using Diagrams to Understand Equivalent Expressions

Example 1

Look at these two expressions.

\((x + 3)(x + 5)\)

\(x^2+8x +15\)

We can show they are equivalent by using a diagram to break apart the different pieces.

Step 1
First, let’s populate the diagram.

Step 2
Then we multiply the corresponding rows and columns.

 

\(x\)

3

\(x\)

\(x \cdot x = x^2\)

\(3 \cdot x = 3x\)

5

\(5 \cdot x = 5x\)

\(3 \cdot 5 = 15\)

This leaves the diagram shown here.

 

\(x\)

3

\(x\)

\(x^2\)

\(3x\)

5

\(5x\)

15

Step 3
We can use this diagram to find our expression in standard form.

So, the expressions are equivalent.

Example 2

The same can be done with two factors using subtraction as well.

\((x − 6)(x − 9)\)

\(x^2 − 15x + 54\)

It is helpful to rewrite the factored form as the addition of negative numbers when subtracting occurs in the factors.

So \((x − 6)(x − 9)\) becomes \((x + (-6))(x + (-9))\). Now the process is the same.

Step 1
Let’s populate the table.

 

\(x\)

–6

\(x\)

    

–9

    

Step 2
Multiply the columns and rows.

 

\(x\)

–6

\(x\)

\(x^2\)

\(-6x\)

–9

\(-9x\)

54

Step 3
Use the diagram to write the expression in standard form.

\(x^2−15x+54\)

The expressions are equivalent.

When the coefficients of the \(x\)-terms are both 1 in the factored form:

Take notice that the linear term (\(x\)-term) in the expression in standard form is the sum of the two numbers in the expression in factored form.

  • In the example above, the term \(-15x\) is the sum of the two numbers –9 and –6.

Also, the constant term is the product of the two numbers in the expression in factored form.

  • In the example above, the term 54 is the product of the two numbers –9 and –6.

Recognizing this will be helpful for switching between standard and factored forms. Remember, this pattern only occurs when the coefficients of the \(x\)-terms in the factors are 1 (because they result in a quadratic term that has a coefficient of 1 as well, \(x^2\)).

Try It: Using Diagrams to Understand Equivalent Expressions

  1. Use a diagram to write \((x + 2)(x + 7)\) in standard form.
  1. The diagram shown breaks down \(x^2−11x +24\).
 

\(x\)

–3

\(x\)

\(x^2\)

\(-3x\)

–8

\(-8x\)

24

Based on the diagram, what is an equivalent factored form of this expression?

Write down your answers, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to use a diagram to help convert between standard and factored forms:

  1. \(x^2+9x +14\)
 

\(x\)

2

\(x\)

\(x^2\)

\(2x\)

7

\(7x\)

14

  1. \((x − 3)(x − 8)\)

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 8.6.3: Rewriting Quadratic Expressions in Standard Form
page.contents:
Activity


Each row in the table contains a pair of equivalent expressions.

Complete the table with the missing expressions. If you get stuck, consider drawing a diagram.

Factored form

Standard form

\(x(x + 7)\)

  
 

\(x^2+ 9x\)
 

\(x^2−8x\)

\((x + 6)(x + 2)\)

  
 

\(x^2+13x +12\)

\((x − 6)(x − 2)\)

  
 

\(x^2−7x +12\)
 

\(x^2+6x + 9\)
 

\(x^2+ 10x + 9\)
 

\(x^2−10x +9\)
 

\(x^2−6x +9\)
 

\(x^2+(m + n)x +mn\)

Write down your answers, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answers:

Factored form

Standard form

\(x(x + 7)\)

\(x^2+7x\)

\(x(x + 9)\)

\(x^2+9x\)

\(x(x − 8)\)

\(x^2−8x\)

\((x + 6)(x + 2)\)

\(x^2+8x+12\)

\((x + 12)(x + 1)\)

\(x^2+13x +12\)

\((x − 6)(x − 2)\)

\(x^2−8x +12\)

\((x − 4)(x − 3)\)

\(x^2−7x +12\)

\((x + 3)(x + 3)\)

\(x^2+6x +9\)

\((x + 9)(x + 1)\)

\(x^2+10x +9\)

\((x − 9)(x − 1)\)

\(x^2−10x +9\)

\((x − 3)(x − 3)\)

\(x^2− 6x +9\)

\((x + m)(x + n)\)

\(x^2+(m + n)x + mn\)

Extending Your Thinking

A mathematician threw a party. She told her guests, “I have a riddle for you. I have three daughters. The product of their ages is 72. The sum of their ages is the same as my house number. How old are my daughters?”

The guests went outside to look at the house number. They thought for a few minutes, and then they said, “This riddle can’t be solved!”

The mathematician said, “Oh yes, I forgot to tell you the last clue. My youngest daughter prefers strawberry ice cream.”

With this last clue, the guests could solve the riddle. How old are the mathematician’s daughters? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your explanation.

Compare your answer:

2, 6, and 6.

If the product of their ages is 72, there are twelve possibilities:

  • 1, 1, 72
  • 1, 2, 36
  • 1, 3, 24
  • 1, 4, 18
  • 1, 6, 12
  • 1, 8, 9
  • 2, 2, 18
  • 2, 3, 12
  • 2, 4, 9
  • 2, 6 ,6
  • 3, 3, 8
  • 3, 4, 6

Because the riddle can’t be solved by knowing the house number (the sum of the three numbers), it must be the case that there are ages that have the same sum. The only sets of ages with the same sum are 3, 3, 8 and 2, 6, 6, which each add up to 14. From the last clue, we know that there is a youngest daughter. The only set of ages that has a “youngest” age are 2, 6, 6, so these are the ages of the three daughters.


Video: Rewriting Quadratic Expressions

Watch the following video to learn more about rewriting quadratic expressions into factored form.

answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: Multiply \((x − 8)(x − 10)\) to check. Since \((x − 8)(x − 10) = x^2− 18x + 80\), you are correct.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The product of \(-12 \cdot (-6)\) is 72, not 80. The answer is \((x − 8)(x − 10)\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The sum of \(-4 + (-20)\) is –24, not –18. The answer is \((x − 8)(x − 10)\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The sum of \(8 + 10\) is 18, not –18. The answer is \((x − 8)(x − 10)\).

page.title: 8.6.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Rewriting Quadratic Expressions in Standard Form

We have had a lot of practice rewriting factored form into standard form. To reverse this process, many of the same skills are needed.

Let’s look at an example.

Example 1

Write \(x^2+16x +63\) in factored form.

To do this, we must think about how you converted from factored form into standard form. First, check if the leading coefficient (for the quadratic term) is 1. If so, then:

  • To find the coefficient of the middle term, 16, we added two numbers together from the diagram.
  • To find the last term or constant, 63, we multiplied two numbers together from the diagram.

So, which numbers, \(a\) and \(b\), have a sum of 16 and a product of 63?

The positive factors of 63 include:

1, 63
3, 21
7, 9

With some reasoning, we find that 7 and 9 are the numbers we want.

So, the factored form of \(x^2+16x +63\) is \((x + 7)(x + 9)\).

Let’s look at another example.

Example 2

Write \(x^2−10x +16\) in factored form.

The sign of the middle term is negative, but we follow the same process since the coefficient of \(x^2\) is 1.

Let’s rewrite the expression as \(x^2+ -10x +16\).

Which numbers have a sum of –10 and a product of 16?

The factors of 16 include:

1, 16
–1, –16
2, 8
–2, –8
4, 4
–4, –4

The numbers we need are –2 and –8 because they have a product of 16 and a sum of –10.

So, the factored form is \((x + (-2))(x + (-8))\). This can be rewritten as \((x − 2)(x − 8)\).

Try It: Rewriting Quadratic Expressions in Standard Form

Find the factored form of each expression.

  1. \(x^2+9x +18\)
  1. \(x^2−12x +35\)

Write down your answers, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to rewrite quadratic equations in standard form into factored form:

  1. \((x + 6)(x + 3)\); Since the coefficients of the \(x\)-terms are both 1, think of two numbers that have a sum of 9 and a product of 18.
  1. \((x − 5)(x − 7)\); Since the coefficients of the \(x\)-terms are both 1, think of two numbers that have a sum of –12 and a product of 35.

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 8.6.4: Finding the Missing Numbers in Pairs of Equivalent Expressions
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

The problems below consist of pairs of equivalent expressions: one in standard form and the other in factored form. Note that the leading coefficients on the quadratic terms are all 1.

Find the missing numbers.

  1. \(x^2 \;+\) __\(x\;+\) __ and \((x + 1)(x + 17)\)

Enter the missing numbers.

Compare your answer:

18 and 17, respectively. The completed expression is \(x^2+18x +17\).


  1. \(x^2+9x +14\) and \((x + 2)(x\; +\) __\()\)

Enter the missing number.

Compare your answer:

7. The completed expression is \((x + 2)(x + 7)\).


  1. \(x^2−7x +10\) and \((x − 2)(x\; −\) __\()\)

Enter the missing number.

Compare your answer:

5. The completed expression is \((x − 2)(x − 5)\).


  1. \(x^2−9x +20\) and \((x\; −\) __)\((x\; −\) __\()\)

Enter the missing numbers.

Compare your answer:

4 and 5. The completed expression is \((x − 4)(x − 5)\).

page.title: 8.6.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. Write \((x + 6)(x + 5)\) in standard form.

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 8.6.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(x^2+11x +30\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Write \((x − 3)(x − 7)\) in standard form.

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 8.6.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(x^2−10x +21\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. An expression in standard form is shown. The diagram below shows it is equivalent to which expression in factored form?

\(x^2+11x +18\)


 

\(x\)

2

\(x\)

\(x^2\)

2

9

\(9x\)

18

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 8.6.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \((x + 2)(x + 9)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. An expression in standard form is shown. The diagram below shows it is equivalent to which expression in factored form?

\(x^2− 12x + 35\)


 

\(x\)

–5

\(x\)

\(x^2\)

\(-5x\)

–7

\(-7x\)

35

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 8.6.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \((x − 5)(x − 7)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Find the factored form of \(x^2+13x +36\).

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 8.6.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \((x + 9)(x + 4)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Find the factored form of \(x^2−14x +48\).

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 8.6.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \((x − 6)(x − 8)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Find the factored form of \(x^2+13x +30\).

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 8.6.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \((x + 3)(x + 10)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Find the factored form of \(x^2−12x +27\).

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 8.6.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \((x − 9)(x − 3)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Find the factored form of \(x^2−13x +22\).

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 8.6.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \((x − 11)(x − 2)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Here are pairs of equivalent expressions: one in standard form and the other in factored form. Find the missing numbers.

\(x^2+20x +96\) and \((x\; +\) __\()(x\; +\) __\()\)

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 8.6.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 12, 8. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 8.6.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Explain how the numbers in a quadratic expression in factored form relate to the numbers in an equivalent expression in standard form.
  • Rewrite a quadratic expression in standard form when given the quadratic expression in factored form.
  • Rewrite a quadratic expression in factored form when given the quadratic expression in the form of \(ax^2+bx +c\).

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 8.6.1: Finding and Reasoning Unknown Factors
    • In this activity, you practiced using reasoning to find unknown factors missing from a problem.
  • 8.6.2: Using Diagrams to Understand Equivalent Expressions
    • In this activity, you learned how to use a diagram to help visualize the process of rewriting a quadratic expression in standard form into factored form.
    • 8.6.2: Self Check
    • 8.6.2: Additional Resources
  • 8.6.3: Rewriting Quadratic Expressions in Standard Form
    • In this activity, you continued learning how to rewrite quadratic expressions in standard form into factored form. This lesson covered expressions in the factored forms \((x + a)(x + b)\) and \((x − a)(x − b)\).
    • 8.6.3: Self Check
    • 8.6.3: Additional Resources
  • 8.6.4: Finding the Missing Numbers in Pairs of Equivalent Expressions
    • In this activity, you used the skills you learned rewriting quadratic expressions to find missing values in a conversion from standard form into factored form.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 8.6.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
